subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Educational Buildings|nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Convents--Singapore|Architecture--Conservation and restoration--Singapore|Schools--Singapore|Singapore--History--1819-1867|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious buildings|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Educational buildings|Schools (Buildings) |Religious buildings
summary: CHIJMES was originally known as the Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus (CHIJ), which was a premier girls’ school established in 1854 by an order of French Catholic nuns. It was originally located within a self-contained city block bound by Victoria Street, Bras Basah Road, North Bridge Road and Stamford Road, and encompassed the English-language primary and secondary schools of CHIJ, a Chinese-medium school called St Nicholas Girls’ School, an orphanage, nuns’ quarters, and a chapel.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Civic and Administrative Buildings|Prisons--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Regulatory role|Streets and Places |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Politics and Government |nlbshtx:Politics and Government|Heritage and Culture |nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities|Public buildings
summary: One of Singapore’s earliest prisons was located at the foot of Pearl’s Hill in Outram. The original civil jail at the site was built in 1847 by Charles Edward Faber; in 1882, a new prison complex was built around the old civil jail by J. F. A. McNair. Originally known as Pearl’s Hill Prison, and Outram Prison in its later decades, it was demolished in 1963 to make way for redevelopment.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Labour and Employment>>Vanishing Trades|Street vendors--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social groups and communities|Vanishing trade
summary: Five-foot-way traders were craftsmen who conducted their businesses along shophouse walkways that were five feet wide. These traders were immigrants of various ethnicities who came to early Singapore and could be found in areas such as Chinatown.

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Associations|nlbshtx:Recreation>>Sports|Singapore Badminton Association|Badminton (Game)--Singapore|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Ball games>>Racket games>>Badminton|Organisations |Sports and games
summary: Established in 1929, the Singapore Badminton Association (SBA) is the official body for local matters pertaining to badminton. During the prewar and immediate postwar periods, the SBA was instrumental in bringing about the rise of local badminton legends such as Wong Peng Soon and Ong Poh Lim, who were part of the team that won the Malaya Thomas Cup in 1949. Individually, they also won other international championships in the 1950s, such as the All England singles and All England doubles. Today, the SBA continues to take charge in the recruiting and training of badminton talents.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>> Public Utilities|Lighting--Singapore|Public Utilities--Singapore|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|Public utilities
summary: Before switching fully to electricity in 1956, Singapore’s street lights were powered by gas from the Kallang Gas Works.

subject: Social groups |Ethnic groups |Eurasians |Clans--Singapore
summary: The Eurasian community is a small but influential ethnic group that has been present in Singapore since the early 19th century. Eurasians are persons with mixed European and Asian lineage. Most Eurasians in Singapore can trace the European part of their ancestry to the Portuguese, Dutch or British, while others are of Danish, French, German, Italian or Spanish descent. The Asian component of their ancestry is usually derived from the Chinese, Malays or Indians.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Education|National Council on Problem Gambling (Singapore)|Compulsive gambling--Singapore|Gambling--Social aspects--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Regulatory role>>Gambling|Education
summary: The National Council on Problem Gambling (NCPG) was appointed by the government in August 2005 as part of Singapore's national framework to address the issue of problem gambling. Its functions include raising public awareness of problem gambling. It also has the authority to bar certain people from the upcoming casinos under the Casino Control Act.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2009.

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Associations>>Sports Associations|Horse racing--Singapore|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Equestrian sports|Sports organisations
summary: The Singapore Turf Club, renowned for its horse racing, is the oldest existing club in Singapore. It was founded by Scottish merchant William Henry Macleod Read, and began as the Singapore Sporting Club on 4 October 1842.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government|Legislators--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Public administration>>Parliament|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Public administration>>Cabinet (Government Councils)|Politics and Government
summary: The Nominated Member of Parliament (NMP) scheme was introduced in 1990 to allow for the appointment of non-elected members of Parliament (MPs) to provide alternative nonpartisan views in the House. NMPs are shortlisted by a Special Select Committee of Parliament from a list of candidates nominated by the public. NMPs serve a term of two-and-a-half years, and up to nine NMPs can be appointed in each Parliament.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Public libraries--Singapore|Branch libraries—Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|Libraries
summary: Geylang East Community Library (known as Geylang East Public Library from 2008) was the seventh branch library opened by the National Library Board (NLB). This standalone library was officially unveiled on 26 July 1988.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Artists|Lim, Tiong Ghee, 1955-|Artists--Singapore--Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Arts>>Painting|Artists
summary: Lim Tiong Ghee (b. 23 March 1955, Singapore–) began as a watercolourist before moving to acrylic and collage. A self-taught artist, he has exhibited extensively and views painting as a medium to portray the quotidian. He gained critical acclaim when his collage From the Turtledove won the top award at the 8th UOB Painting of the Year Competition in 1989.

subject: nlbshtx:Arts>>Performing Arts>>Music|Bands (Music)--Singapore|Popular music--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Music>>Popular music|Music
summary: The Quests was a popular Singapore band of the 1960s. Formed in 1961 by Jap Chong, Raymond Leong, Henry Chua and Lim Wee Guan, and later joined by guitarist Reggie Verghese and singer Vernon Cornelius, the band was considered the most successful local band of that era. It started out by performing cover versions of British and American songs, but went on to record a number of singles and albums containing original compositions. The band is best known for its original hit song “Shanty”.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Political Leaders|nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Pioneers|Rizal, José, 1861-1896|Nationalists--Philippines--Biography|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Political ideologies>>Nationalism|Politicians |Pioneers
summary: José Protasio Rizal Mercado y Alonso Realondo (b. 19 June 1861, Calamba, Luzon, Philippines–d. 30 December 1896, Manila, Philippines), popularly known as José Rizal, was a doctor, intellectual and patriot. He helped to inspire the Philippine Revolution from 1896 to 1898, which ended over two centuries of Spanish rule. Rizal made four visits to Singapore during his lifetime, and passed through again shortly before his execution.

subject: nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Food|Noodles--Singapore|Cooking, Singaporean|nlbdltx:Cookery>>International and regional cooking>>Chinese|Heritage and Culture |Ethnic foods
summary: Hokkien prawn noodle soup is a popular local dish made up of Hokkien mee (thick yellow noodles) in a broth of pork bones and prawn stock made from prawn heads and shells, and garnished with bean sprouts, slices of pork and prawn, and kangkong (water spinach). Hokien Street was once the most popular place for eating the dish.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Religious Leaders|Olcomendy, Michael, 1901-1977|Catholic Church--Bishops--Biography|Bishops--Singapore--Biography|Bishops--Malaysia--Malaya--Biography|nlbdltx:Philosophy, psychology and religion>>Religion>>Christianity|Religious leaders
summary: Michael Olcomendy (b. 29 August 1901, St. Etienne de Baigorry, France–d. 4 July 1977, Singapore) was the first Catholic archbishop of Singapore. He rose from being a parish priest to become the metropolitan archbishop of the Malacca-Singapore Archdiocese, then the archbishop of Singapore from 1973 to 1976. He served the church in Malaya and Singapore for over 50 years before retiring as an archbishop emeritus.

subject: nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Food|Cookery, Singaporean|Cookery, Malay|Cookery, Peranakan|nlbdltx:Cookery>>International and regional cooking>>Malay|nlbdltx:Cookery>>Types of meals>>Side dishes|Ethnic foods
summary: Otak-otak, also known as otah, is a dish of Malay and Peranakan origins. It is a blend of raw fish, chopped onions, coconut milk, herbs and spices bound together with egg. The puree is usually wrapped in a banana leaf and grilled over an open charcoal fire or in the oven. The dish can also be prepared by steaming the wrapped puree in a wok filled with boiling water for about five minutes. Otak-otak is commonly served as an accompaniment to a meal of nasi lemak.

subject: nlbshtx:Events>>Historical Periods>>World War II and Japanese Occupation (1939 - 1945)|Prisoner-of-war camps--Singapore|World War, 1939-1945--Concentration camps--Singapore|Singapore--History--Japanese occupation, 1942-1945|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|1942-1945 Japanese occupation
summary: During the Japanese Occupation of Singapore from 1942 to 1945, two prisoner-of-war camps were located in the area bounded by River Valley Road and Havelock Road. Due to their proximity, these camps were often referred to collectively as the River Valley Road Camp, but were sometimes also referred to as Havelock Road Camp. European, Australian, Indian and local prisoners-of-war (POWs) were interned at this camp. After the war, the site was first redeveloped into a Fraser & Neave (F&N) factory, and then replaced by the Fraser Suites condominium and the Valley Point shopping mall adjacent to it. The location was marked as a historic site in 2002.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Political Leaders|Lim Kim San, 1916-|Cabinet officers--Singapore--Biography|Politicians--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Public administration>>Cabinet (Government Councils)|Politicians
summary: Lim Kim San (b. 30 November 1916, Singapore–d. 20 July 2006, Singapore) was a former politician best known for his contributions to public housing in the 1960s during his term as chairman of the Housing and Development Board (HDB). Throughout his political career, Lim held various ministerial portfolios including finance, education, defence, communications and the environment. He also chaired the Council of Presidential Advisers as well as boards of various organisations such as the Port of Singapore Authority (PSA), Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and Monetary Authority of Singapore.

subject: nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Festivals and Celebrations|Id al-Adha--Singapore|Fasts and feasts--Islam|Religious festivals--Singapore|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Customs>>Festivities|Ethnic festivals
summary: Hari Raya Haji (which means “great day of the haj” in Malay), also known as Aidiladha (alternatively spelt as Eid al-Adha or Eid Adha) or the Great Day of Sacrifice, is a Muslim festival that falls on the 10th day of Zulhijjah (the 12th month in the Islamic calendar). The festival marks the end of the haj, which is the Muslim pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia. It also commemorates the willingness of the Islamic prophet Ibrahim to sacrifice his son Ismail in an act of obedience to Allah (God). One of the main rituals of the festival is the korban, which involves the sacrificial slaughtering of livestock. It is one of two major Muslim festivals in Singapore that are celebrated as public holidays (the other being Hari Raya Puasa).

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Branch libraries--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|Libraries
summary: Siglap Branch Library (Part-time) (1 July 1954 - March 1981) was the second Branch of the Raffles Library. It provided library services to the residents living in Siglap and Katong.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2010.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>public Buildings|nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Health|Communicable diseases--Hospitals--Singapore|Hospitals--Singapore|Singapore--History--1867-1942|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Health services|Public buildings |Public health
summary: The Communicable Disease Centre is the national centre for the management of communicable and infectious diseases. It is also one of Singapore’s oldest hospitals. It began in 1907 as a quarantine camp for patients with infectious diseases. Between 1907 and 1931, buildings were added, and in 1913, the camp became known as the Government Infectious Diseases Hospital and later, the Middleton Hospital. In 1985, Middleton Hospital was absorbed into Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and renamed Department of Communicable Disease and then Communicable Disease Centre.

subject: nlbshtx:Events>>Disasters|Aircraft accidents--Singapore|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Safety administration>>Air transportation|Events |Transportation |Accidents
summary: A Qantas-BOAC Constellation G-ALAM airliner named Able Mike crashed during its landing at the now-defunct Kallang Airport on 13 March 1954 at 3.04 pm. The plane was making a scheduled flight from Sydney to London and had stopped over at Darwin, Australia, and Jakarta, Indonesia, before making its way to Singapore. The crash, which was the first major air disaster in Kallang Airport’s history, resulted in 33 fatalities – all 31 passengers as well as two crew members were killed. Seven crew members, including the pilot Captain Trevor William Hoyle, survived the crash.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Branch libraries--Singapore|Public libraries--Singapore|Libraries--Singapore|Singapore--History--1965-1990|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|Libraries
summary: Bukit Merah Community Library, located at Bukit Merah Central, Singapore, was the fourth full-time Branch Library built by the National Library in its decentralised plan to bring library services nearer to people's homes. The Library is the first amongst the Branch Libraries to have an Audio-Visual Room specially designed for such a purpose. For weeks after the Library's opening on 29 December 1982, it was heavily used.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2005.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Transportation|Street names--Singapore|Urbanization--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|Streets and Places |Transportation
summary: The original Clemenceau Avenue stretched from Newton Circus to the southern bank of the Singapore River. It was conceived as an alternative access between the northwestern sector of the city and Orchard Road, which was then served by Cairnhill Road and Cavenagh Road. Today, Clemenceau Avenue is cut by the roadways and tunnels of the Central Expressway (CTE).

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Suburbs--Singapore|Street names--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Engineering>>Transportation engineering|Streets and Places
summary: Tuas is an area located in the southwestern region of Singapore. Landmarks in the district include the Tuas Industrial Estate, Second Link and Tuas Naval Base. The construction of the megaport known as Tuas Terminal is currently underway and expected to be completed in the 2020s.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>National Security>>Defence|Civil defense--Singapore|Fire departments--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Security>>Civil defence|National defence
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) is a uniformed organisation that provides emergency services to the nation both during peacetime and under crisis. It serves not only as a fire-fighting authority, but also provides first-aid and rescue services, and acts as an educator on fire safety procedures.

subject: nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Customs and Traditions|Singapore-- Social life and customs|Rites and ceremonies--Singapore|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Customs>>Festivities|Customs
summary: A hongbao (or ang pow in Hokkien) is a gift of money inserted into a red packet. Red is considered a symbol of luck, life and happiness. Hongbaos are given as a token of good wishes during auspicious occasions such as Chinese New Year and weddings.

book_title: Singapore's first motorcycle trip around the world
subject: nlbshtx:Recreation>>Sports|nlbshtx:Events>>Historical Periods>>Independence and Nation-Building (1965-)|Special events--Singapore|Motorcycling--Singapore|Fund raising--Singapore|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Motoring|Sports and games |1965-1970 Nation building
summary: Michael and Sonya Fong were Singapore's first couple to set out on a world motorcycle trip, which they called "Baby Quek's Big Adventure", on 17 September 1995. They travelled for nearly two years, returning on 14 May 1997. Riding their 1,000 cc BMW motorcycle, Baby Quek, their trip managed to raise funds for children's charities through the Singapore Community Chest (ComChest).
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2005.

subject: nlbshtx:Nature>>Animals|Bats--Singapore|Rare mammals--Singapore|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Zoology>>Mammals|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Zoology>>Endangered animals|Wildlife
summary: Bats belong to an order of mammals known as Chiroptera, a term that comes from the Greek words cheiro (“hand”) and ptera (“wing”), aptly describing their most distinctive feature. There are about 1,100 species of bats in the world and 30 have been documented in Singapore. The Singapore Red Data Book (2008) classifies seven species of bats as “critically endangered”, just one step away from local extinction. They are threatened mainly by habitat loss. Conservation would thus require an effective protection of their habitats and keeping human disturbance to a minimum.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Regional libraries--Singapore|Libraries--Singapore|Singapore--History--1990-|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|Libraries
summary: Woodlands Regional Library (WRL) was officially opened on 28 April 2001. It is the first full-fledged regional library under the National Library Board (NLB).

subject: nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Industries|Supermarkets--Singapore|Business enterprises--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services>>Retail and wholesale|Trade and industry
summary: The earliest supermarket in Singapore, Cold Storage Company Ltd was established in 1903. It pioneered the processing and distribution of hygienic food supplies in Malaya.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Customs and Traditions|Street names--Singapore|Funeral rites and ceremonies--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Customs>>Death customs|Streets and Places |Customs
summary: Sago Lane is a one-way road in Chinatown connecting South Bridge Road to Banda Street. It was named for the many sago factories that were located there in the 1840s. Sago Lane was also known for the Chinese “death houses”.

book_title: Tan Sri Datuk Professor Ahmad Ibrahim
subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Pioneers|Ahmad Mohamed Ibrahim, 1916-1999|Judges--Singapore--Biography|Attorneys general--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Public administration|Pioneers
summary: Tan Sri Datuk Professor Ahmad Ibrahim B.A., M.A., LLD. a.k.a. Ahmad bin Mohamed Ibrahim (b. 12 May 1916 Singapore - d. 17 April, 1999, Gombak, Malaysia). Educated at Victoria Bridge School, Raffles Institution, Raffles College, and Cambridge University where he graduated with first class honours in economics and law. Appointed a Singapore Magistrate in 1946, District Judge and Magistrate in 1955, he became Singapore's first State Advocate General in 1959, and Singapore's first Attorney-General in 1966. He was awarded the Honorary Degree of Doctor of Laws (LL.D) from the University of Singapore on 5 June 1965. Known to the law fraternity as an expert on Muslim law, he drafted the Administration of Muslim Law Act which revamped the Syariah Court's jurisdiction, and established the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore. From 1969 he worked in Malaysia as Professor of Legal Studies at the Faculty of Economics and Administration, University of Malaya, next as Dean of the Faculty of Law, University of Malaya, and then as Sheikh and Dean, Kulliyyah of Laws, International Islamic University, Malaysia.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2005.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Libraries--Singapore|Public libraries--Singapore|Branch libraries--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Libraries and information centres|Libraries
summary: The Queenstown Community Library located at 53 Margaret Drive, Singapore 149297, was opened on 2 May 1970. It was the first full-time Branch Library, built by the National Library in its plan to decentralise home reading services. It pioneered several firsts amongst branch libraries, including becoming the first fully air-conditioned branch in 1978, computerising its loan services in 1987, and lending video cassettes in 1997. It was refurbished in 2003.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2004.

subject: nlbshtx:Arts>>Literature>>English (Singapore) Literature|English newspapers--Singapore|Electronic newspapers--Singapore|Singapore--History--1990|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Communication and media|Literature
summary: Project Eyeball was Singapore's first integrated print and digital newspaper.It was launched on 12 August 2000 by the Singapore Press Holdings (SPH). Targeted at Internet-savvy readers between the ages of 20 and 40, Project Eyeball aimed to carry news of interest to engage the wired generation. Unfortunately, high operating cost and poor circulation rate led to the newspaper's demise less than a year after its launch.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Ratnam, S. Shan, 1928-2001|Obstetricians--Singapore--Biography|Gynecologists--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Medical science>>Medical profession|Personalities
summary: Shanmugaratnam s/o Sittampalam, better known as Shan S. Ratnam (Emeritus Professor; b. 4 July 1928, Ceylon–d. 6 August 2001, Singapore), was a medical pioneer and leader in the field of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (O&G), both in Singapore and internationally. At the peak of his career, he represented Singapore as the secretary general of the Asia and Oceania Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology (AOFOG), and was the president and a member of the executive board of the International Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology. Through these two organisations, he helped place Singapore in the international medical arena and established himself as a prominent figure in the O&G world.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Health|Hospitals--Singapore|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Health services|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|Public health
summary: Changi General Hospital (CGH), located in Simei, serves the residents living in eastern and northeastern Singapore. Pitched as the first purpose-built regional hospital, CGH was formed through an amalgamation of Changi Hospital and the former Toa Payoh Hospital on Thomson Road. It was officially opened on 28 March 1998, although its history had begun as early as 1935.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Colonial Administrators|nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities|Tessensohn, John Edwin, 1855-1926|Colonial administrators--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Public administration|Colonial administrators |Heritage and Culture
summary: John Edwin Tessensohn (b. 8 April 1855, Malacca–d. 26 September 1926, Singapore), better known as Edwin Tessensohn, was a prominent citizen in colonial Singapore. He was the president of the Singapore Recreation Club for 25 years (non-consecutively between the years of 1894 and 1926) and helped establish the Eurasian Association in 1919. His dedication to public service earned him wide respect in the community and led to his appointment as the first Eurasian legislative councillor in the Straits Settlements in 1923.

subject: nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Food|Noodles--Singapore|Cooking, Singaporean|Cooking (Beef)--Singapore|nlbdltx:Cookery>>International and regional cooking>>Chinese|Ethnic foods
summary: Several varieties of beef noodles exist in Singapore, but the term usually refers to a soup-based dish made of kway teow (flat rice noodles) accompanied with either thinly sliced lean beef, beef tripe and other innards, or beef balls. The beef broth is often clear and sometimes has added spices. It may also be served dry and topped with a thick gravy. The dish is often eaten with a specially concocted chilli sauce. The best-known beef noodles in Singapore are the Teochew and Hainanese versions.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Audio-visual library service--Singapore|Libraries--Singapore|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|Libraries
summary: Audiovisual Services were first introduced in December 1982 when the Arts Resource Centre (ARC) was established in the Reference Services Division at the National Library at 91, Stamford Road. The service was made possible by funds provided by the Cultural Foundation. The ARC, occupying an area of about 175 square metres, was officially opened on 10 January 1983.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2006.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Chan, Patricia Li-Yin, 1954-|Women swimmers--Singapore--Biography|Athletes--Singapore--Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Water sports>>Swimming|Personalities
summary: Patricia Chan Li Yin (b. 12 April 1954, Singapore–), popularly known as Pat Chan, was the “Golden Girl” of regional swimming between 1965 and 1973. The most accomplished in a family of talented swimmers, Chan dominated the 100-metre freestyle event. She captured 39 gold medals over five Southeast Asian Peninsular (SEAP) Games (now known as the Southeast Asian Games), often setting new records at each sports meet.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Chia, Boon Leong, 1925-?|Football players--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Ball games>>Football|Personalities
summary: Chia Boon Leong (b. 1 January 1925, Singapore–) is a former footballer who played for Singapore in the Malaya Cup (now known as the Malaysia Cup) and other representative matches. He also represented China at the 1948 Olympic Games in London. Nicknamed “Twinkletoes”, Chia was regarded as one of the most skilful football players in Malaya during the 1940s and ’50s. He was voted 19th on The Straits Times list of Singapore’s Greatest Sports Stars in 1999.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Authors|Jeyaretnam, Philip--Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|Authors, Singaporean--Biography|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Literatures>>East and Southeast Asian literature>>Singapore literature|Writers
summary: Philip Jeyaretnam (b. 1964, Singapore–) is a senior counsel and an award-winning writer. He is the youngest son of veteran opposition politician and lawyer, Joshua Benjamin Jeyaretnam, popularly known as JBJ. Jeyaretnam has written two bestsellers, First Loves and Raffles Place Ragtime. Among the literary awards he has received are the Airey Neave Award, Southeast Asia Write Award and the National Book Development Council of Singapore’s Highly Commended prize. He is also the recipient of the National Arts Council’s 1993 Young Artist Award. Jeyaretnam has been chairman of the Singapore Writers’ Festival steering committee since 2007 and a member of the Public Service Commission since 2009. He is also a managing partner of law firm Rodyk & Davidson LLP.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Community Leaders|Tang, Choon Keng, 1901-2000|Businessmen--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services>>Retail and wholesale|Community leaders
summary: Tang Choon Keng (b. 12 September 1901, Swatow, China–d. 3 September 2000, Singapore) was a Teochew who established the landmark department store C. K. Tang in Singapore. Popularly known as C. K. Tang, he was also known as Tang Un Tien and nicknamed the “Tin Trunk Man” and “Curio King”.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Monuments|Lighthouses--Singapore|Monuments--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Architectural structure|National monuments
summary: Raffles Lighthouse is located on Pulau Satumu, 23 km southwest of Singapore, at the western entrance of Singapore Straits. Designed by John Bennett, the lighthouse was named after and dedicated to the memory of the founder of Singapore, Thomas Stamford Raffles. The foundation stone was laid in 1854 by William J. Butterworth, then governor of the Straits Settlements. The lighthouse began daily operations from November 1855.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Cemeteries--Singapore|War memorials--Singapore|Japanese--Singapore|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Death and bereavement|Streets and Places
summary: The Japanese Cemetery Park at 22 Chuan Hoe Avenue was established in 1891 to serve the burial needs of Japanese residents in Singapore. Said to be the largest and best-preserved Japanese cemetery in Southeast Asia, the site measures 30,000 sq m and has an estimated 910 tombstones. Those interred here include Japanese businessmen, professionals, tradesmen and prostitutes in Singapore, as well as a number of war dead from World War II. The cemetery was closed to burials in 1973 and declared a memorial park in 1987.

subject: Arts |nlbshtx:Arts
summary: Xinyao (新谣) is a genre of music that typically refers to Mandarin ballads composed, written and performed by youths in Singapore. Started in the late 1970s, xinyao was at its peak in the 1980s and propelled many local singers and singer-songwriters to stardom, several of whom successfully transitioned to the commercial sector. Big names often associated with the xinyao movement include Eric Moo (巫启贤), Billy Koh (许环良), Liang Wern Fook (梁文福) and Roy Loi (黎沸挥).
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings|Hospitals--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Health services|Public buildings
summary: Opened in 1961, Mount Alvernia Hospital is a non-profit private hospital in Singapore. It was founded by the Franciscan Missionaries of Divine Motherhood to provide healthcare services based on Christian values and Catholic teachings. Located at 820 Thomson Road, the complex encompasses a hospital, a 24-hour clinic, health screening centre, specialist clinics, pharmacies and retail outlets.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Chia, John Keng Hock, 1913-1993|Football players--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Ball games>>Football|Personalities
summary: John Chia Keng Hock (b. 1913, location unknown–d. 1 December 1993, Singapore) was a former footballer who represented Singapore several times in the Malaya Cup. Nicknamed “Cannonball Chia” and “The Bull” for his playing style, Chia was an all-round sportsman who also represented his country as a cricketer and excelled in other sports.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Military Sites|nlbshtx:Geography>>Geographical Areas and Countries>>Singapore Offshore Islands|Islands--Singapore|Military training camps--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Security>>Army|Military facilities |Singapore offshore islands
summary: Pulau Pawai is an island located south-west of Singapore. Known as Alligator Island during colonial times, the island was described as having a conspicuous summit of about 147 ft, and was extensively fringed with coral reefs. A large reef found in 1946 separates Pulau Pawai and Pulau Sudong. The island’s land area has increased over the years – measuring 68.8 ha in 1980 and 111.9 ha in 2002.

subject: nlbshtx:Nature>>Plants|Mangosteen|Tropical fruit--Peninsulas--Southeast Asia|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Agriculture>>Fruit crops|Plants
summary: The mangosteen (Garcinia mangostana) is an evergreen tree native to Southeast Asia. It is grown widely in Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines. The crop is also found in certain parts of India and Sri Lanka where conditions are favourable. The dark purple fruit with its sweet, white edible segments is considered a delicacy.

subject: nlbshtx:Streets & Places|nlbshtx:Nature & Environment|Streets & Places|Nature & Environment
summary: Marina Barrage is a government-commissioned dam built across the mouth of Marina Channel to create Singapore’s 15th reservoir, Marina Reservoir. Officially opened on 31 October 2008, it separates the water in Marina Basin from the seawater. It has been considered an engineering marvel because of its magnitude and complexity, and it was the subject of an August 2008 episode of Discovery Channel’s documentary, Man Made Marvels Asia. The barrage is dubbed a three-in-one project as it serves three objectives: creating a new source of water supply, acting as a tool for flood control, and providing a new lifestyle attraction.

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Companies|Business enterprises--Singapore|Ointments|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Healthcare and medicine|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Medication and therapies>>Traditional Chinese medicine|Business enterprises
summary: Leung Kai Fook Medical Company (Pte) Ltd is the maker of Axe Brand Universal Oil (also known as Axe Brand Medicated Oil), a popular brand of medicated oil recognised by many people around the world by its logo, which features an arm holding an axe. Axe Brand Medicated Oil is colourless and has a pleasant aroma due to its unique blend of eucalyptus, menthol, camphor and other essential oils. For more than 80 years, it has been used by adults and children as a treatment for giddiness, headache, travel sickness, stomachache, insect bites and other minor ailments.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Health|Children |Pediatrics--Singapore--Biography|Children--Health and hygiene--Singapore--Biography   |Rural health--Singapore--Biography   |Rural children |Foreign nurses |nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Public health |Personalities
summary: Ida Mabel Murray Simmons (b. 1881 or 1888, unknown–d. 7 January 1958, Stirling, Scotland) was a public health matron who transformed maternal and infant health care standards in Singapore. She improved facilities and services in rural areas, and educated families  on infant health, thereby sharply reducing the acute infant mortality rate.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Pioneers|Businesspeople--Singapore--Biography|Pioneers--Singapore--Biography|Persons by political role |Entrepreneurs |keyword:Seah, Liang Seah, 1850-1925|Community leaders |Politicians |Philanthropists |Businesspeople |Pioneers
summary: Seah Liang Seah (b. 1850, Singapore–d. 14 September 1925, Singapore) was a wealthy local-born Chinese merchant who was known for being the Chinese representative on the Straits Settlements Legislative Council. He was a keen proponent of British rule and co-founded the pro-British Straits Chinese British Association (SCBA).
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Law|Judges |Judges--Singapore--Biography|Legal occupations |Personalities |Law
summary: James Walter Davy Ambrose (b. 1909, Penang, Malaya–d. 28 October 1992, Singapore), an ethnic Indian, was a high court judge in the Singapore legal system. Between 1936 and 1958, he held various portfolios in the legal and judicial services of Malaya, including the post of magistrate in Penang and district judge in Singapore.  Ambrose then reached the peak of his career with his appointment as a high court judge in Singapore in 1958, serving in the position for 10 years before his retirement.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>National Security>>Civil Unrests|Subversive activities--Singapore|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social conflict>>Civil disobedience|Civil unrests
summary: In May 1987, the Ministry of Home Affairs arrested 16 people under the Internal Security Act (ISA) for their involvement in a “Marxist conspiracy”. They were detained without trial for between one month and three years. Tan Wah Piow, a former University of Singapore Students’ Union president residing in the United Kingdom, was named the mastermind behind the plot.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Pioneers|Hanitsch, Karl Richard, 1860-1940|Library directors--Singapore--Biography|Natural history museum directors--Singapore--Biography|Singapore--History--1867-1942|nlbdltx:Arts>>Art museums, collections and exhibitions|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|Pioneers
summary: Karl Richard Hanitsch (Dr) (b. 22 December 1860, Grossenstien, Sachsen-Altenburg, Germany–d. 11 August 1940, London, England) served as director of the Raffles Library and Museum for 24 years, from 1895 to 1919. He became the first director of the Raffles Museum and Library when the title of Curator and Librarian was changed to Director in September 1908. Hanitsch’s long tenure saw the Raffles Library and Museum increase significantly in its collections, patronage and building size despite the meagre annual government grant. He also held the positions of honorary treasurer of the Straits Branch, Royal Asiatic Society, and editor and secretary of the Journal of the Asiatic Society.

subject: nlbshtx:Recreation>>Sports|Water polo--Singapore|Water polo--Records--Singapore|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Water sports>>Water polo|Sports and games
summary: Water polo in Singapore started with a group of boys who just wanted to have fun. However, a sense of camaraderie and team bonding soon pushed them to compete and they eventually emerged victorious. Today, water polo is a national sport.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Authors|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Literatures>>East and Southeast Asian literature>>Singapore literature|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Literatures>>English literatures>>English poetry|sash:Ho, Poh Fun, 1946-|sash:Women poets--Singapore--Biography|sash:Women authors--Singapore--Biography|Writers
summary: Ho Poh Fun (b. 1946, Singapore–) is a poet and writer. Her poetry collection, Katong and Other Poems, was published in 1994.

subject: nlbshtx:Events>>Historical Periods>>World War II and Japanese Occupation (1939 - 1945)|War memorials--Singapore|Singapore--History--Japanese occupation, 1942-1945|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|1942-1945 Japanese occupation
summary: The Bukit Batok Memorial, which consisted of the Syonan Chureito and British Memorial Cross, was built during the Japanese Occupation to honour dead soldiers of the Japanese and British forces. Located at Bukit Batok Hilltop (present Bukit Batok Nature Park) in Lorong Sesuai, off Bukit Timah Road, the memorial was destroyed by the end of World War II. Today, all that remains at the memorial site is a flight of steps leading to where the monuments once stood.

subject: Economy |nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry|Politics and Government |nlbshtx:Politics and Government|Streets and Places |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Trade and industry
summary: The China-Singapore Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) project was launched in 1994 to develop a model industrial township within the city of Suzhou in China’s Jiangsu province. The first flagship joint project between the two governments, a key feature of the SIP involves the transfer of Singapore’s “software” – industrial development model and public-administration experience – to China. At the time, China was keen to study Singapore’s development model, while Singapore saw China as an important market for the country’s regionalisation drive. Both governments believed that the SIP, developed and managed based on Singapore’s approach, would be attractive for foreign direct investments. Profitable since 2001, the Singapore–China cooperation zone currently spans an area of 80 sq km. Besides industrial developments, the integrated township also encompasses residential areas, commercial and recreational facilities, as well as educational institutions.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: Politics and Government |nlbshtx:Politics and Government|Organisations |nlbshtx:Organisations
summary: Established on 21 November 1954, the People’s Action Party (PAP) has been the ruling political party in Singapore since the city-state became an independent nation in 1965. During the early years of independence, national survival and nation-building were the foremost concerns of the PAP government. At the time, Singapore was plagued by a series of acute problems including over-population, unemployment, housing shortage and racial tension. Led by then Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, the PAP government implemented a range of economic and social policies to address the issues and was able to overcome the situation with remarkable success. By constantly fielding new candidates for each general election and recruiting new members, the PAP maintains a systematic self-renewal process at all levels. In 1992, Lee Kuan Yew was succeeded by Goh Chok Tong as the party’s secretary-general, who was then succeeded by Lee Hsien Loong in 2004.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Food|Cooking (Lamb and mutton)|Indian cooking|Cooking, Singaporean|nlbdltx:Cookery>>International and regional cooking>>Indian|nlbdltx:Cookery>>Types of meals>>Soups|Ethnic foods
summary: Kambing soup or sup kambing is a spicy broth of mutton soup, traditionally made with goat meat that is cut into bite-sized chunks and stewed in spices, then served hot with toasted bread on the side. This dish is associated with the Indian Muslim community.

subject: nlbshtx:Events>>Disasters|Petroleum--Offshore storage--Singapore|Fires--Singapore|Disasters--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Security>>Civil defence|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Safety administration|Accidents
summary: On 28 September 2011, a fire broke out at an oil refinery owned by Royal Dutch Shell on Pulau Bukom. The blaze began near a system of pipelines carrying various petroleum products and lasted for 32 hours before being extinguished. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) firefighters subsequently described it one of the most complex and intense fires they had ever faced.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Libraries--Singapore|Public libraries--Singapore|Branch libraries--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|Libraries
summary: The Marine Parade Community Library, opened on 10 November 1978, was the third full-time library built by the National Library under its plan to decentralise home reading services and to bring the Library nearer to the people. It was the first Branch Library to be designed for full airconditioning. It also had an Auditorium with a stage and dressing rooms, besides a multi-purpose Lecture Hall.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2004.

book_title: First nonstop flight between Singapore and Los Angeles
subject: nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Transportation|Airlines--Singapore|Aeronautics, Commercial--Singapore|Special events--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services>>Transportation and logistics|Transportation
summary: On 3 February 2004, Singapore Airlines (SIA) launched its first A345 LeaderShip nonstop flight service between Singapore and Los Angeles, United States. The 14,700-kilometre journey was made possible using the new, long-range Airbus aircraft, the A340-500. The inaugural Flight SQ20 departed at 4 pm from Singapore Changi Airport and landed 16 hours later at 4 pm local time on the same day in Los Angeles. It set a new record for the world’s longest direct commercial flight when it was first introduced. From Los Angeles to Singapore, its return flight on SQ19 took 18½ hours, departing at 8 pm Los Angeles time.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>> Health|Business enterprises--Singapore|Medical care--Singapore|Integrated delivery of health care--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Healthcare and medicine|nlbshtx:Organisations>>Companies|Public health |Business enterprises
summary: Established in 1976, Raffles Medical Group is one of Singapore’s largest private integrated healthcare providers. It operates a network of medical and dental facilities throughout the island, and provides specialised medical services such as evacuation and repatriation. In addition, the group is a shareholder Raffles Hospital and manufactures its own range of healthcare products. Raffles Medical has diversified into other business activities such as consultancy services.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Historic Buildings|nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Synagogues--Singapore|Historic buildings--Singapore|Jews--Singapore|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious buildings|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social groups and communities|Historic buildings |Religious buildings
summary: The Maghain Aboth Synagogue, which translates to mean “Shield of our Fathers”, is the oldest surviving synagogue in Singapore and Southeast Asia. Situated at 24/26 Waterloo Street, the synagogue was built in 1878 and gazetted as a national monument on 27 February 1998. It is managed by the Jewish Welfare Board.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Tan, Chay An, 1871-1916|Philanthropists--Singapore--Biography|Businessman--Singapore--Biography|Rubber plantations--Singapore--History|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Agriculture, fishing and forestry|Personalities
summary: Tan Chay Yan (b. December 1871, Malacca–d. 6 March 1916, Malacca), also known as Tan Chay An or Chen Qixian, was the first rubber planter in Malaya. He pioneered an industry that transformed the region’s fortunes, and used his wealth to support causes such as education.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Educational Buildings|High school buildings--Singapore|Junior high schools |National monuments |Educational organisations |Schools (Buildings)
summary: The Chinese High School was founded in 1919 as the first secondary school in Singapore offering a modern education using the Chinese language. Initially operating out of bungalows on Niven Road, the school relocated to its current location along Bukit Timah Road in 1925. The clock tower building on the school’s campus is now a gazetted national monument. Today, it is known as Hwa Chong Institution, a premier education institution in Singapore that consists of both secondary school and junior college sections.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: Biographers |Nurses--Singapore--Biography|Autobiography--Women authors  |Chinese writers |Child slaves |nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Authors|Lim, Janet, 1923- |Personalities |Writers
summary: Janet Lim Chiu Mei (b. 14 July c.1923, Hong Kong–5 August 2014, Brisbane, Australia), born Kwek Chiu Mei, was Singapore’s first Asian hospital matron but is better remembered as its first Asian memoirist. Lim’s bestselling memoir, Sold for Silver, recounts her childhood sale into servitude by her mother, her subsequent journey from abuse and exploitation to freedom and a fulfilling career, as well as her near-death wartime experiences.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2014.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Community Leaders|Lim, Chong Pang, 1904-1956|Businessmen--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social groups and communities|Community leaders
summary: Lim Chong Pang (b. 6 June 1904, Singapore d. 21 July 1956, Singapore) was a prominent businessman and long-time member of the Singapore Rural Board. Chong Pang Village and Chong Pang Road (both expunged) were named after him.

subject: nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Industries|Motion picture industry--Singapore|Real estate business--Singapore|Corporations--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Leisure and entertainment|Trade and industry
summary: Cathay Organisation is a leisure and entertainment group with businesses in film exhibition and distribution as well as cinema, hotel and leisure centre management. Cathay is also involved in property management, and advertising and event organisation. Founded by the Loke family in 1935, the group’s traditional business was in film distribution, exhibition and production, with Cathay studios in Malaya, Singapore and Hong Kong playing an important role in the film industry from the 1950s to the ’70s. Cathay’s revenues amounted to around S$70 million in 2009.

subject: nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Labour and Employment>>Vanishing Trades|Carvers (Decorative artists)--Singapore|Skilled labor--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Decorative arts>>Carving and carvings|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services|Vanishing trade
summary: Chinese seal carvers are traditional craftsmen who make Chinese seals by carving characters and designs onto the base of blocks of stone, wood, ivory, jade and other solid material. Seal carving was a lucrative trade in the past as seals were used in Chinese business transactions to authenticate the validity of documents. Many seal carvers set up their businesses in Chinatown. By the early 1980s, however, the trade and profession had gone into decline as the signature and other methods of verification began replacing seals as means of authentication.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Political Leaders|Nathan, S. R., 1924-|Presidents--Singapore--Biography|Politicians--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Political process>>Leadership|Politicians
summary: Sellapan Ramanathan (b. 3 July 1924, Singapore–22 August 2016, Singapore), commonly known as S. R. Nathan, served as the sixth president of Singapore from 1 September 1999 to 31 August 2011. He is Singapore’s longest-serving president. Prior to his presidency, Nathan held key positions in security, intelligence and foreign affairs, and chaired various companies and academic institutions.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Political Leaders|Politicians--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Political process>>Leadership|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Public administration>>Parliament|Politicians
summary: Lee Chiaw Meng (李昭铭) (Dr) (b. 28 February 1937, Singapore–d. 23 May 2001, Singapore) served as the member of Parliament (MP) for Farrer Park (1968–80) and then for Tanah Merah (1980–84), minister for education (1972–75) and minister for science and technology (1975–76).

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Villages--Singapore|Chinese--Dwellings--Singapore|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social groups and communities|Streets and Places
summary: Several Chinese villages in the northern part of Singapore, from Kranji through Woodlands to Yishun.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2011.

subject: Medisave (Singapore) |Central Provident Fund (Singapore)
summary: Medisave is a national savings scheme in which individuals contribute part of their monthly wages to their Medisave accounts to meet their personal or immediate family’s hospitalisation expenses. Implemented on 1 April 1984 by the Ministry of Health, the scheme was designed to enable individuals to pay their medical expenses through their own savings. The government opted for this self-financing mechanism as a way of balancing the supply and demand for healthcare services to keep healthcare costs in check.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Church architecture--Singapore|Methodist church buildings--Singapore|Historic buildings--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious buildings|Religious buildings
summary: Wesley Methodist Church is located at 5 Fort Canning Road, in the Museum precinct of the Central Region in Singapore. Originally called the Methodist Episcopal Church, it was renamed Wesley Methodist Church in 1910. The main building was completed in 1908 and designed in the English Gothic style by Scottish architect David McLeod Craik from architectural firm Swan & Maclaren.

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Associations|Associations, institutions, etc.--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts|Organisations
summary: The Equator Art Society was created in 1956 as an artists’ group that promoted the social realist art style in Singapore. It was also a nationalist and anti-colonialist society that was most active during the 1960s, when the country was going through several political changes. Artists in the group were primarily concerned with depicting the masses, especially the poorer classes, besides promoting nation building.

subject: nlbshtx:Events |nlbshtx:Politics and Government |Referendums |Events |Politics and Government
summary: The referendum on merger with the Federation of Malaysia, also known as the Singapore National Referendum, was held on 1 September 1962. The idea for a referendum to be held was championed by then Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of the People’s Action Party (PAP). The official purpose of the referendum was to allow the people of Singapore to express their preference on the terms of merger with Malaysia. The opposition political parties, notably the Barisan Sosialis (BS), were not satisfied with the framing of the referendum as it did not allow voters the choice of rejecting merger altogether. Despite such dissatisfactions, the referendum was carried out with three contentious options for merger being offered to voters.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Historic Buildings|nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Islamic shrines--Singapore|Tombs--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious buildings|Historic buildings |Religious buildings
summary: Keramat Radin Mas is the shrine of Radin Mas Ayu, a Javanese princess who shielded her father from being killed, only to be killed herself. According to the legend, Radin Mas was a beautiful and filial daughter loved by her father but hated by her stepmother. Radin Mas was brought to Singapore by her father as an infant, and lived in a village at Telok Blangah. Her father, a skilful warrior prince, married into the royal family in Singapore. How much of the legend is true is unclear. Radin Mas’s tomb lies at the foot of Mount Faber, behind Mount Faber Lodge Condominium, and still receives visitors.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Library storage centers--Singapore|Bibliographical services--Singapore|Technical services (Libraries)--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|Libraries
summary: The Library Supply Centre, located in Changi South, houses the Library Support Services (LSS) Division of the National Library Board. LSS performs the library functions of collection development, supply-chain management and bibliographic services.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2006.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|nlbshtx:Recreation>>Places of Interest|Mountains--Singapore|Parks--Singapore|Historic parks--Singapore|Singapore--History--1819-1867|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Travel>>Asia>>Southeast Asia|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Leisure and entertainment|Streets and Places |Places of interest
summary: Mount Faber is located in the Bukit Merah area in the central region of Singapore. Standing at 106 m above sea level, it was originally known as Telok Blangah Hill. It was renamed Mount Faber in July 1845 after Charles Edward Faber of the Madras Engineers, who built a narrow winding road to the summit for the new signal station and flagstaff. Mount Faber was thereafter also referred to as Bukit Bendera (Flag Hill). At the top of Mount Faber, a cable car system connects it to the island of Sentosa.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Historic Buildings|nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>> Customs and Traditions|Historic buildings--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Architectural structure|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social groups and communities|Historic buildings |Customs
summary: Located off Serangoon Road, Bendemeer House was formerly called the House of Whampoa or Whampoa House. It was a mansion designed and built in 1840 by Hoo Ah Kay (better known as Whampoa), a Kapitan China (“leader of the Chinese people”) of Singapore. In 1964, the government acquired the historic building and the 30-acre estate on which it stood for the development of the Kallang Basin housing and industrial project. The building was demolished in 1968 to make way for urban development.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Public libraries--Singapore|Branch libraries--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|Libraries
summary: Whampoa Branch Library, which opened on 30 September 1981, was a part-time branch library of the National Library. It closed on 30 July 1987 after eight years in operation.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings>>Libraries|Libraries--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|nlbdltx:Arts>>Art museums, collections and exhibitions|Libraries
summary: The Raffles Museum and Library reopened to the public at the end of 1945, after three and a half years of Japanese Occupation in Singapore. While there are discrepancies over the actual date of the re-opening, it is certain the library had opened by 5 December 1945. In the post-war years between 1945 and 1960, the library went through several changes of administration, separated from the museum, and moved to a new building.

subject: nlbshtx:Events>>National Celebrations|National Day (Singapore)|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social interaction|National celebrations
summary: Swing Singapore began as a street party in 1988 and continued as a part of the National Day celebrations until 1992 when variations of the event were starting to be held. For example, the Millennium Swing Singapore in 1999 made the annual street party a New Year’s countdown celebration instead. Similarly, Orchard Road had been the main venue for Swing Singapore when it first started. But, this has since moved to other locations such as the Padang and the Singapore Expo.

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Companies|nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Transportation|Neptune Orient Lines Ltd|Shipping--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services>>Transportation and logistics|Business enterprises |Transportation
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) is a global transportation company established in 1968 as Singapore’s national shipping line. Through the container shipping brand, APL, NOL’s core business activities include all aspects of global cargo container transportation. The shipping carrier is currently owned by the French CMA CGM, the world’s third-largest container shipper, after it bought over Temasek Holdings’ majority stake in NOL in December 2015.

subject: Streets and Places |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Nature and Environment |nlbshtx:Nature|Geography and Travels |nlbshtx:Geography
summary: Officially opened on 28 February 2014, River Safari is Asia’s first river-themed zoo. The S$160-million park attraction is spread across 12 ha of land in Mandai. Focused on freshwater habitat conservation, the safari houses the world’s biggest freshwater aquarium and one of the largest collections of freshwater animals. The park is home to 6,000 animals from 200 species, of which 40 are threatened. Among River Safari’s star attractions is a pair of giant pandas, Kai Kai and Jia Jia.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: Organisations |nlbshtx:Organisations|Communications |nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Communications|Heritage and Culture |nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities|Education |nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Education
summary: The South Seas Society, Singapore (南洋学会; Nanyang Xuehui) is a non-profit scholarly society dedicated to Southeast Asian studies. Founded in 1940, it is the first academic society set up by overseas Chinese based in Southeast Asia focusing on this field. The society frequently publishes books and texts, and periodically organises conferences, seminars, public lectures and exhibitions. Its flagship publication, Journal of the South Seas Society, which began shortly after its founding, still runs to this date.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: Streets and Places |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Heritage and Culture |nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities
summary: Located not far from the Istana and the Cathay Building, MacDonald House has a relatively plain and nondescript facade. Completed in 1949, it was the first office building in Southeast Asia to be wholly air-conditioned, and was construed to symbolise optimism and confidence in postwar Singapore. The building is perhaps most remembered as the site of a bombing on 10 March 1965 during the Indonesia–Malaysia Konfrontasi (Confrontation, 1963–1966).
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

book_title: Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR)
subject: Politics and Government |nlbshtx:Politics and Government|Organisations |nlbshtx:Organisations|Economy |nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry|Trade and industry
summary: The Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR), previously known as the National Science and Technology Board until January  2002, is Singapore’s driver of scientific research. A statutory board under the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI), A*STAR aims to advance the economy and improve lives by growing the knowledge-intensive biomedical, research, scientific and engineering fields. Among the entities under the A*STAR umbrella are scientific institutes, an extensive scholarship programme and commercialisation bodies.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Heritage and Culture |Streets and Places
summary: Caledonian Hotel, established in 1904, was one of the principal hotels in Singapore during the early 20th century. It was also said to be “the only British hotel in Singapore” at the time.

subject: Streets and Places |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places
summary: Simei is one of the five subzones of the Tampines planning area located in the eastern region of Singapore. It is bounded by the Pan-Island Expressway (PIE), Upper Changi Road East and Bedok Park Connector. Measuring 225 ha in size, Simei makes up 11 percent of the total land area of Tampines New Town and is largely residential in nature. Public housing development in Simei began in 1984 and its first residents moved in 1986. As at 2015, it houses a population of 42,710 residents. Simei estate has a wide range of amenities including a hospital, primary to tertiary educational institutions, retail outlets and a community centre. While Simei is supported by its own commercial and shopping establishments, residents also tap on existing facilities available in the neighbouring Tampines town centre.

subject: nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Customs and Traditions|Heritage and Culture |Customs
summary: Funeral rituals form an important part of Chinese social life. The Chinese undertake these rituals partly out of filial piety, and partly out of the belief that there is a continued relationship between the living and dead. Although traditional rituals have gradually been simplified over the years, current practices continue to reflect these beliefs. This article focuses on the burial customs of non-Christian Chinese who subscribe to the folk religions of Taoism, Buddhism or Confucianism. The rituals practised by such Singaporean Chinese differ according to dialect group and may incorporate elements from more than one dialect group.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: Streets and Places |Heritage and Culture |Politics and Government |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Civic and Administrative Buildings
summary: Sri Temasek is a 19th-century bungalow designated as the prime minister’s official residence. It was formerly the residence of the colonial secretary. While the house has been unoccupied since 1959, it was used regularly for meetings and official social events during the 1960s and 1970s. The building deteriorated during a period of disuse, but was restored in 2008. The house is situated within the grounds of The Istana.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Mosques--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious buildings|Religious buildings
summary: Alkaff Kampung Melayu Mosque, previously known as Alkaff Mosque, was originally located on Jalan Abdul Manan. Its present site at 200 Bedok Reservoir Road was officially opened on 29 July 1995.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Nasir Jalil, 1955-2011|Football players--Singapore--Biography|Football players--Malaysia--Terengganu--Biography|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Ball games>>Football|Personalities
summary: Nasir Jalil (b. 1955–d. 8 June 2011, Terengganu, Malaysia) was a footballer who played for Singapore and Terengganu in the Malaysia Cup. Nicknamed “Crazy Horse” for his tireless style of play, Nasir won the Malaysia Cup for Singapore and later reached the final for Terengganu. After moving to Terengganu in 1982, Nasir settled there and eventually became a Malaysian citizen.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Education|National Institute of Education (Singapore)|Teachers colleges--Singapore|Universities and colleges--Singapore|nlbdltx:Education>>Higher education>>Colleges and universities|Education
summary: The National Institute of Education (NIE) is Singapore’s only teacher training institution. In addition to engaging in initial teacher preparation, the NIE also provides continuing education and life-long learning to teachers, and conducts extensive, cutting-edge research in education that enhances NIE programmes.

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Companies|Computer storage device industry--Singapore|USB (Computer bus)|nlbdltx:Computers and information technology>>Computer hardware>>Storage and peripherals|Business enterprises
summary: Trek 2000 International Limited is the Singaporean company that created the ThumbDrive, a thumb-sized universal serial bus (USB) data storage device which revolutionised the way digital data is stored and transferred in personal computers. Headquartered in Singapore’s Loyang Industrial Estate, the public listed company has offices in many parts of the world. It was included in Forbes’s list of Best Small Companies in the World in 2000 and 2002, and named Best Managed Small Company in Singapore by AsiaMoney in 2003. The ThumbDrive has also been recognised as one of the top 50 engineering achievements in Singapore since 1965.

subject: nlbshtx:Nature>>Plants|Water chestnuts--Southeast Asia|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Agriculture>>Fruit crops|Plants
summary: Water Chestnut (Trapa natans), an aquatic plant, belongs to the family Trapaceae. It is not to be confused with another aquatic plant of tather similar name, Chinese water chestnut (Eleocharis dulcis) of the family Cyperaceae, which is a popular ingredient in Southeast Asian and Chinese cooking.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2005.

subject: nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Transportation|Express highways--Singapore|Roads--Singapore|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Engineering>>Transportation engineering|Transportation
summary: Seletar Expressway (SLE) is one of the nine high-capacity expressways in Singapore. It is 12 km long and built between 1992 and 1998 at a cost of $150 million. It connects Bukit Timah Expressway (BKE) in Kranji to the junction of Tampines Expressway (TPE) and Central Expressway (CTE) in Yio Chu Kang. Its completion links up the existing expressways in Singapore.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Cemeteries--Singapore|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social groups and communities|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|Streets and Places
summary: Fort Canning Cemetery was one of the first burial grounds for Christians in Singapore. Located on Fort Canning Hill, the grounds encompassed two burial sites. The first was used from 1819 to 1822, and the second from 1822 to 1865. Fort Canning Cemetery was closed to further burials in 1865, and eventually converted into a park.

subject: nlbshtx:Events|Restrooms|Congresses and conventions--Singapore|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Healthy living>>Public health|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Healthy living>>Environmental health|Events
summary: The inaugural World Toilet Summit 2001 was held from 19–21 November 2001 at the Singapore Expo. Hosted by the Restrooms Association of Singapore, along with 16 other toilet associations, the purpose of the summit was to promote an in-depth discussion on global sanitation issues.

subject: nlbshtx:Events>>Historical Periods>>World War II and Japanese Occupation (1939 - 1945)|nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities|Malaya--History--Japanese occupation, 1942-1945|Singapore--History--Japanese occupation, 1942-1945|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Malaysia|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|1942-1945 Japanese occupation |Heritage and Culture
summary: Endau Settlement was a 300,000-acre agricultural settlement set up at Endau, in the Malayan state of Johor during the Japanese Occupation for Chinese settlers. It was considered the most successful self-sufficiency scheme initiated by the Japanese authorities to ease the food supply problem in Singapore. Under the scheme, the Chinese population in Singapore was encouraged to resettle outside Singapore, in areas where they could farm and live off the land. Endau Settlement was also known as New Syonan Model Farm.

subject: Local foods
summary: Mee soto is a spicy noodle soup dish that combines the Indonesian chicken broth known as soto ayam with thick yellow Hokkien noodles.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government>> Health|Institutional care--Singapore|Day care centers for people with disabilities-- Singapore|nlbdltx:Health and medicine>>Health services|Public health
summary: Metta Home for the Disabled, at Woodlands Street 31, was officially opened on 21 April 2001. The home is managed by the Metta Welfare Association, a charity organisation which runs other homes for the less fortunate and the elderly.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2004.

subject: _Programmes:READ! Singapore |Reading
summary: READ! Singapore is a nationwide campaign organised by the National Library Board (NLB) that aims to promote a reading culture among Singaporeans. An annual event since its inception in 2005, READ! Singapore features book discussions and related activities like film screenings, performances, meet-the-author sessions, workshops and reading marathons, all of which are organised around a particular theme and reading list.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Trade|Coffeehouses--Singapore|nlbdltx:Cookery>>Beverages>>Coffee and tea|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services>>Retail and wholesale|Trade and industry
summary: Killiney Kopitiam is a Hainanese coffee shop formerly known as Kheng Hoe Heng Coffeeshop. It was established in late 1919 by an immigrant from the island of Hainan in China. Located at 67 Killiney Road, it was bought over in 1992 by former broker Woon Tek Seng. The coffee shop is well known for its kaya toast, French toast, coffee and tea. Killiney Kopitiam ventured overseas in 2001, and now has outlets in countries such as Malaysia and Indonesia.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government|Postal codes--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Public administration|Communications |nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Communications|Heritage and Culture |nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities|Streets and Places |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Streets and Places|Politics and Government
summary: The six-digit postal code system was introduced in Singapore in 1995. It was adopted by Singapore Post (SingPost) with the aim of facilitating the automation of mail processing, in particular the mail-sorting system.

subject: Biographies |Accountants
summary: Percy Reginald Hill (b. 1888, Lancashire, England –d. 1950, Sydney, Australia) was a chartered accountant who lived in Singapore and Malaya between 1906 and 1919. He is best remembered for his collection of photographs depicting bygone ways of everyday life in Singapore and Malaya that was donated to the National Library of Singapore in 2008.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2013.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Temples, Hindu--Singapore|Historic buildings--Singapore|Singapore--History--1867-1942|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious buildings|Religious buildings
summary: Sri Krishnan Temple (a.k.a Sri Krishna Temple), on Waterloo Street was established in 1870. It is the only South Indian Hindu temple in Singapore dedicated exclusively to Sri Krishna and his consort Rukmini.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2004.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Public Buildings|Centers for the performing arts--Singapore|Art centers--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|Public buildings
summary: The Esplanade – Theatres on the Bay is an arts centre built on reclaimed land in the Marina Bay area. It features a 1,600-seat concert hall, a 2,000-seat theatre and other smaller performing arts venues. The Esplanade also contains art installation spaces, a library, retail units, restaurants and cafes.

subject: nlbshtx:Events|nlbshtx:Nature>>Animals|Captive elephants--Singapore|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Zoology>>Animal behaviour|Events |Wildlife
summary: For about a week in early June 1990, Singaporeans were captivated by media reports of runaway elephants on Pulau Tekong. This was reportedly the first time in recent history that elephants had swum across the Johor Straits to Tekong, an island used by the Singapore Armed Forces for military training. The wild Asian elephants (Elephas maximus) were first sighted by national servicemen on 29 May 1990. With the collaboration and co-operation of the Singapore and Malaysian governments, the Singapore Zoo, Malaysian wildlife authorities and Tekong army personnel, the bull elephants were captured about a week later on 7 June 1990.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Historic Buildings|Historic buildings--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Public and commercial buildings|Heritage and Culture |nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities|Historic buildings
summary: Stamford House, located at the junction of Stamford Road and Hill Street, is an ornate building designed in the Venetian Renaissance style favoured during the Victorian era. Built in 1904, it was designed by Swan and Maclaren architect R. A. J. Bidwell as a commercial entity. The building was better known as a hotel until it was sold in 1963 to a commercial enterprise. It was then acquired by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in 1984 for conservation and redevelopment. The building will be reopened in the third quarter of 2015 as part of a new hotel.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2015.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Mosques--Singapore|Historic buildings--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious buildings|Religious buildings
