subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Artists>>Cultural Medallion Recipients|Yeo, Thomas, 1936- --Biography|Artists--Singapore--Biography|Art--Collectors and collecting--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Painting|Award winners |Acrylic painting |Oil painting |Cultural Medallion Recipients (Art)
summary: Thomas Yeo (b. 22 April 1936, Singapore–) represents one of Singapore's second-generation artists who studied in the West. His work, since the 1960s, has been infused with Western ideas although he never completely abandoned the images and impressions of Asia, and featured these prominently in his art pieces. Conferred the Cultural Medallion in 1984, Yeo continues his active participation in the art community in Asia.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Artists>>Cultural Medallion Recipients|Artists--Singapore--Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Arts>>Painting|Teo, Eng Seng, 1938--Biography|Award winners |Visual Arts |Painters (Art) |Cultural Medallion Recipients (Art)
summary: Teo Eng Seng (张永生) (b. 14 December 1938, Singapore–) was a recipient of the Cultural Medallion in 1986 for his contributions to visual arts. In 1960, The Singapore Free Press described Teo as “a youth who holds the record of being the first schoolboy in Singapore to hold a one-man art exhibition”. His invention of the paperdyesculp as a  medium ranks as one of the most significant achievements of second-generation artists in Singapore.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Artists>>Cultural Medallion Recipients|nlbshtx:Arts>>Performing Arts>>Theatre|Varathan S., 1934- --Biography|Dramatists, Tamil--Singapore--Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Literatures>>Indic and Dravidian literatures>>Tamil literature|nlbdltx:Arts>>Theatre|Award winners |Theatre |Theatrical actors |Theatrical directors |Cultural Medallion Recipients (Theatre)
summary: S. Varathan (b. 22 February 1934, Singapore -), recipient of the National Arts Council Cultural Medallion in 1984, has played an active role in the local Tamil drama scene as an artiste, director, founder, producer, writer and researcher.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2008.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Artists>>Cultural Medallion Recipients|Abisheganaden, Paul, 1914- --Biography|Musicians--Singapore--Biography|Conductors (Music)--Singapore--Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Arts>>Music>>Conducting|Award winners |Musicians |Conductors (Music) |Educators |Cultural Medallion Recipients (Music)
summary: Paul Selvaraj Abisheganaden (b. 27 March 1914, Penang, Straits Settlements–d. 31 August 2011, Singapore) was a musician and conductor, who was awarded the Cultural Medallion in 1986. Born in Penang, Abisheganaden came to Singapore in 1916 at the age of two, when his family re-located in search of better opportunities. He was taught the violin by his father and pursued further studies in London’s Guildhall School of Music. Abisheganaden founded the Singapore Chamber Ensemble in 1950, which became the most active amateur orchestra and chorus in Singapore for almost 30 years. His book Notes Across the Years is a definitive history of Western classical music in Singapore. His pioneering work in music paralleled an illustrious career in education and administrative services.

subject: Politics and Government |nlbshtx:Politics and Government
summary: The Singapore Labour Party (SLP) was inaugurated on 1 September 1948. It was fronted largely by English-speaking Indians who underwent the British education system, were exposed to publications on British politics and involved in labour unions. The SLP met with some electoral successes such as winning two out of seven seats at the April 1951 Legislative Council general election and three out of six seats at the December 1951 City Council election. Since its formation, however, the party had been wrecked with internal struggles for power, dissension and squabbles, which eventually weakened and fractured the organisation, leading to its demise six years after it was established. On 21 August 1954, the SLP merged with the Singapore Socialist Party to form the Labour Front.

subject: Heritage and Culture |Events |nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Festivals and Celebrations
summary: Chinese New Year celebrations are accompanied by specific rites and rituals with strict prohibitions and taboos.

book_title: Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus
subject: Education |nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Educational Buildings|Organisations |nlbshtx:Organisations
summary: Convent of the Holy Infant Jesus (CHIJ) is the oldest Catholic girls’ school in Singapore. Founded in 1854 by the French sisters of the Congregation of the Holy Infant Jesus, the school was established at the corner of Bras Basah Road and Victoria Street (present site of CHIJMES). It moved to Toa Payoh in 1983, and henceforth the primary and secondary sections were renamed CHIJ Primary (Toa Payoh) and CHIJ Secondary (Toa Payoh).

subject: Government agencies |nlbshtx:Organisations>>Government Agencies|nlbshtx:Politics and Government|nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry|Economy |Organisations
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) encourages economic growth and creates employment so that Singaporeans can lead better lives. Its strategies are based on a free-market system and outward-oriented economic policies.

subject: Education |nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Education
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) launched the “Teach Less, Learn More” (TLLM) initiative in 2005 to improve the quality of teaching and enhance student learning in Singapore. TLLM built on the “Thinking School, Learning Nation” vision, which had been introduced in 1997 to create an education system that nurtures creativity, critical thinking and a passion for lifelong learning.

subject: Politics and Government |Organisations |nlbshtx:Politics and Government|nlbshtx:Organisations
summary: The Communist Party of Malaya (CPM), also known as the Malayan Communist Party, was a political party active in Singapore, the Federation of Malaya and later Malaysia. It was founded in 1930 and dissolved in 1989.

subject: Organisations |Economy |nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry|nlbshtx:Organisations>>Companies
summary: The Chinese Commercial Bank (华商银行) was founded in 1912 by Lim Peng Siang, a Hokkien businessman who established the Ho Hong group of companies. Set up by the Hokkien business community, the Chinese Commercial Bank had many leading figures involved in the establishment – such as Yin Suat Chwan, Yeo Cheng Hai, Tan Jiak Kim, Tan Chay Yan, Lim Kwee Eng and Tan Sian Cheng. Lee Choon Guan and Lim Boon Keng were appointed chairman and vice-chairman respectively at the time of its founding. As one of the earliest Chinese banks in Singapore, the Chinese Commercial Bank popularised the use of cheques among Chinese traders and merchants. In 1932, affected by the economic downturn, the bank amalgamated with Ho Hong Bank and Oversea-Chinese Bank to form the Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC).

subject: Personalities |Economy |Community and Social Services |nlbshtx:Personalities|nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry|nlbshtx:Community and Social Services
summary: Kwek Leng Joo (24 April 1953, Singapore–16 November 2015, Singapore) was a prominent businessman, photographer and philanthropist. The younger son of Kwek Hong Png, founder of conglomerate Hong Leong Group, Kwek was the deputy chairman of City Developments Ltd (CDL) and held directorships in Hong Leong Finance Ltd and Hong Leong Investment Holdings Pte Ltd, among other positions. He is also known for his pioneering role in the corporate social responsibility (CSR) movement and as a photographer.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government|Land use--Planning--Singapore|Urban renewal--Singapore|City planning--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>National development>>Land use|Politics and Government
summary: Development guide plans (DGPs) are detailed short- to medium-term land-use plans completed between 1993 and 1998 as part of a comprehensive review of the Master Plan 1985. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA), the national land-use planning agency, divided Singapore into 55 planning areas and drew up a DGP for each of these areas. A blueprint of the living, working and leisure environment in Singapore, the 55 DGPs together formed the overall Master Plan 1998, which was gazetted on 22 January 1999. The URA released the first of its 55 DGPs in 1993. The final DGP was released in 1998.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Authors>>Cultural Medallion Recipients|Wong, Yoon Wah, 1941- --Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|Authors, Singaporean--Biography|Poets--Biography|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Literatures>>East and Southeast Asian literature>>Singapore literature|Cultural Medallion Recipients (Literature)
summary: Wong Yoon Wah (b. 13 August 1941, Perak, Malaysia–) is one of the few Singaporeans who excel as an international poet, critic and scholar. Prolific in both creative and academic writing, Wong has published more than 20 collections of prose, poetry, and academic writings on Chinese and comparative literature in Chinese and English. For his commitment to promoting literature regionally, Wong was awarded the Southeast Asia Write Award (1984), the Cultural Medallion (1986), and the ASEAN Cultural Award (1993).

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Aroozoo, Frank Perciva, 1900-1969|School principals--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Education>>Secondary education|Personalities |School principals
summary: Percival Frank Aroozoo (b. 13 April 1900, Singapore–d. 15 March 1969, Singapore) was headmaster of Gan Eng Seng School from 1938 to 1955. He was responsible for the opening of the new school building at Anson Road in 1951, and oversaw the school's transition from a primary to a secondary school. He was also instrumental in shaping the school's identity through his design of the school crest and the creation of the school creed.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Religious Buildings|Temples--Singapore|Temples, Buddhist--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Religious Buildings|Religious buildings
summary: Sasanaramsi Burmese Buddhist Temple Singapore is located at 14 Tai Gin Road. The temple, which subscribes to the Theravada tradition, has been providing Theravada Buddhist services to the Buddhist community in Singapore since its earliest days. Built at a cost of S$4 million and completed in 1992, it is the first and only Burmese Buddhist temple built outside of Myanmar in the traditional Burmese architectural style. Its marble Buddha statue is also the largest enshrined outside of Myanmar. The present temple was designed according to the traditional Burmese concept by Venerable Sayadaw U Pannya Vamsa, who also initiated the temple’s registration with the Registrar of Societies in 1985.

subject: nlbshtx:Nature>>Plants|Bougainvillea--Singapore|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Agriculture>>Horticulture>>Flowers and ornamental plants|Plants
summary: Bougainvillea (Bougainvillea sp.) is a popular tropical and sub-tropical ornamental flower tha belongs to the family Nyctaginaceae. The Nyctaginaceae plant family  consists of 28 genera and 250 species. Spectacular bougainvillea of different varieties have been cultivated and used in landscaping Singapore, helping to establish the Republic as a garden city.

subject: nlbshtx:Nature>>Plants|Hibiscus--Singapore|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Agriculture>>Horticulture>>Flowers and ornamental plants|Plants
summary: The common hibiscus (Hibiscus rosa-sinensis) is an evergreen shrub belonging to the cotton family Malvaceae which comprises about 300 species.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Pioneers|L. M. Harrod, 1905-?|Librarians--Singapore--Biography|Library directors--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:People and communities>>Social groups and communities|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Public libraries|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Library and information science>>Library and information services|Pioneers
summary: Leonard Montague Harrod (b. 21 May 1905, Horsham, England–d. 12 March 1984), commonly referred to as L. M. Harrod, was appointed the librarian of the Raffles Library on 8 September 1954, and then its director from January 1955 to December 1959. A qualified librarian, Harrod contributed greatly to the development of the library system, the planning, and progress of the Raffles Library. He was formerly the Chief Librarian and Curator of Islington Public Libraries, and was the pioneer of Singapore’s then new public library.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Educational Buildings|nlbshtx:Politics and Government>>Education|Universities and colleges--Singapore|Raffles College--History|nlbdltx:Arts>>Architecture>>Educational buildings|nlbdltx:Education>>Higher education>>Colleges and universities|Education |Schools (Buildings)
summary: Raffles College was set up in 1928 at 469 Bukit Timah Road as a college for higher education in the arts and sciences. Its formation was the result of a scheme to commemorate the centenary of the founding of Singapore by Stamford Raffles (Sir). In 1949, Raffles College merged with King Edward VII College of Medicine to form the University of Malaya, which became known as the University of Singapore in 1962, and then the National University of Singapore (NUS) in 1980 after merging with Nanyang University. In 1981, NUS moved out of its Bukit Timah site to its current location at Kent Ridge. The Bukit Timah site was subsequently occupied by several other tertiary institutions before it became NUS’s Bukit Timah Campus in 2005.

subject: nlbshtx:Nature>>Plants|Mango--Southeast Asia|Tropical fruit--Southeast Asia|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Agriculture>>Fruit crops|nlbdltx:Cookery>>Types of meals>>Desserts|Plants
summary: The cultivated mango (Mangifera indica Linn.) originated in the Indo-Burma region, and it has been grown in India for the last 6,000 years. It is an important commercial crop not only in India, but also in Southeast Asian countries such as the Philippines, Thailand, Burma, Indonesia and Malaysia, as well as Sri Lanka. The mango is a common dessert fruit in Asia. Dozens of varieties exist, with Thailand’s Tong Dum being one of the more popular kinds. The mango is the national fruit of India, Pakistan and the Philippines, and the national tree of Bangladesh. The tree plays an important role in rituals and religious ceremonies in South and Southeast Asia, while mango leaves are used to decorate homes during weddings and celebrations.

subject: nlbshtx:Arts>>Performing Arts|Festivals--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Arts|Performing arts
summary: The South East Asia Cultural Festival was held in Singapore from 8 to 15 August 1963. It featured a series of performances involving about 1,500 artistes from 11 Asian countries. The main events were held at the National Theatre, which has since been demolished, and the Victoria Theatre. The festival was a milestone in the history of Southeast Asia, as it marked the first time that so many countries in the region came together to participate in a single cultural event.

subject: nlbshtx:Nature>>Plants|Durian--Southeast Asia|Tropical fruit--Southeast Asia|nlbdltx:Science and technology>>Agriculture>>Fruit crops|nlbdltx:Cookery>>Types of meals>>Desserts|Plants
summary: The name “durian” was derived from the Malay word for thorns, duri. The world-renowned naturalist, Alfred Russel Wallace, said this about the fruit: “It is like a buttery custard flavoured with almonds, intermingled with wafts of flavour that call to mind cream cheese, onion sauce, brown sherry and other incongruities... It is neither acid, nor sweet, nor juicy, yet one feels the want of none of these qualities, for it is perfect as it is”. There were others who also spoke strongly about the fruit, but to contrary effect. Probably no other fruit has had so many contradictory descriptions written of its smell and flavour. Durians are not plucked but allowed to fall, which is when they are best consumed.

subject: nlbshtx:Architecture and Landscape>>Building Types>>Historic Buildings|Red Dot Design Museum|Industrial design--Awards--Singapore|Museums--Singapore|nlbdltx:Arts>>Design>>Product and industrial design|nlbdltx:Arts>>Art museums, collections and exhibitions|Historic buildings
summary: The Red Dot Design Museum is located at 11 Marina Boulevard. It is the second Red Dot Design Museum in the world. Established in November 2005, the museum showcases innovative product design and hosts events and exhibitions. It was the anchor tenant in the former headquarters of the Singapore Traffic Police, a conserved colonial-era building. The museum moved to Marina Bay in 2017.

subject: nlbshtx:Arts|Arts--Awards--Singapore|Art publicity--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Culture and community>>Arts|nlbdltx:Arts|Arts
summary: The Cultural Medallion honours individuals who have achieved excellence in the fields of literary arts, performing arts, visual arts and film, and contributed to Singapore’s cultural environment. The award is conferred by the president of Singapore and administered by the National Arts Council (NAC). Instituted in 1979 by Ong Teng Cheong in his capacity then as the acting minister for culture, the Cultural Medallion is the nation’s highest award for the arts. Candidates for the award are nominated every year, and the Cultural Medallion is awarded if there are suitable candidates.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Chan, Kim Boon, 1851-1920|Translators--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Linguistics>>Translating and interpreting|Personalities
summary: Chan Kim Boon (b. 1851, Penang–d. 1920, Singapore?) is a Peranakan who gained fame with his Baba Malay translations of Chinese classics such as Romance of the Three Kingdoms and Water Margin.

subject: nlbshtx:Geography>>Geographical Areas and Countries>>Singapore Offshore Islands|Islands--Singapore|nlbdltx:Law and government>>National development>>Land use|Singapore offshore islands
summary: A tiny islet, Pulau Anak Bukom (which means 'child of Bukom' in Malay) used to lie next to its much larger and heavily industrialised parent, Pulau Bukom.  Through land reclamation, it was merged with its parent, on which the enormous Shell oil refinery is located. Shell’s association with the island dates back to 1891. The word ‘bukum’ is said to come from the Malay name for a shell called ‘rangkek bukom’ which is wide at one end and tapers to a narrow point– the shape of Bukom Besar prior to man-made changes to it. The word ‘bukum’ is also said to come from ‘hukum’ which is Malay (from Arab origins) for order, command, judicial decision or sentence. Pulau Anak Bukom was noted as a nesting and roosting site for resident shore birds.
copyright: All Rights Reserved. National Library Board Singapore 2009.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Loi, Adrin Boon Sim, 1955-|Businessmen--Singapore--Biography|Baked products industry--Singapore|Beverage industry--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Manufacturing industries>>Food, beverages and tobacco|Personalities
summary: Adrin Loi Boon Sim (b. 1955, Singapore–) is the executive chairman of food and beverage chain Ya Kun International. The youngest son of Ya Kun founder, Loi oversaw the expansion of the company from a single outlet to a chain spanning over 50 outlets in Singapore and close to 50 across the globe.

subject: Politics and Government |nlbshtx:Politics and Government
summary: The Singapore government introduced national service (NS) in 1967 to develop and maintain a credible defence force manned by Singapore’s citizens, given the withdrawal of British military forces from the city-state by the 1970s. Since then, all male Singapore citizens and permanent residents are liable for NS from the age of 18. There have been several changes to the NS scheme over the years; currently, each enlistee is required under the Enlistment Act to serve as a full-time national serviceman (NSF) for a maximum of two years.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Artists>>Cultural Medallion Recipients|Lim, David Kim San, 1933-|Composers--Singapore--Biography|Conductors (Music)--Singapore--Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Arts>>Music|Award winners |Cultural Medallion Recipients (Music) |Conductors (Music) |Music directors |Musicians
summary: David Lim Kim San (b. 7 May 1933, Singapore–) has a diverse career in music which spanned over four decades, including educator, administrator, producer, advocate, vocalist and conductor. Lim’s contribution to the school band and choral movements began in the 1960s when he spearheaded the music education scene in Singapore, together with an elite group of specialists. He is also noted for his role as conductor of the Singapore Youth Choir (SYC) for more than two decades. In 1974, he led the choir at the Llangollen International Musical Eisteddfod in Wales, where it won first prize in the youth category. Lim was conferred the Cultural Medallion in 1979 for his contributions to the nation. He was also awarded the COMPASS Meritorious Award in 2001.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Tan, Eng Yoon, 1928-2010|Male athletes--Singapore--Biography|Coaches (Athletics)--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Sports, recreation and travel>>Sports|Personalities
summary: Tan Eng Yoon (b. 8 January 1928, Singapore – d. 30 January 2010, Singapore) was a former Singapore athlete, coach and sports administrator. As an athlete, he participated in the Olympic Games, Asian Games and inaugural Southeast Asian Peninsular (SEAP) Games in 1959, where he won a gold medal for the 400-metres hurdles. As the national athletics coach for over a decade, Tan mentored a generation of Singapore’s athletes. He was also an administrator at the Singapore Sports Council (SSC) and Football Association of Singapore (FAS), as well as president of the Singapore Olympians Association (SOA).

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Companies|nlbshtx:Ethnic Communities>>Food|Snack food industry--Singapore|Corporations--Singapore|Cookery, Singaporean|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Manufacturing industries>>Food, beverages and tobacco|nlbdltx:Cookery>>International and regional cooking>>Southeast Asian|Business enterprises |Ethnic foods
summary: Old Chang Kee is a food retail chain best known for its Hainanese-style curry puffs, which were first sold in 1956. The business was bought over and revamped in 1986, and has since expanded to a chain of over 70 outlets in Singapore. The outlets are located at shopping malls, petrol stations and other high human traffic areas. Its menu includes mostly takeaway deep-fried snacks, as well as quick dine-in meals at selected cafes. The chain sells more than 40,000 curry puffs daily. Listed on the Singapore Exchange, Old Chang Kee also has a presence in Malaysia, Indonesia and China.

subject: nlbshtx:Organisations>>Companies|nlbshtx:Commerce and Industry>>Industries|Shirt industry--Singapore|Clothing trade--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Services>>Retail and wholesale|Business enterprises |Trade and industry
summary: CYC is a clothing firm best known for its custom-made shirts and corporate wear. Founded as CYC Shanghai Shirt Company in 1935, it became a leader in Singapore’s shirt industry and attracted customers from Malaysia and Indonesia during its heyday. Now known as CYC The Custom Shop, the company has an impressive clientele, including international and corporate clients as well as leaders in the political and business fields.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Ip, Yiu Tung, 1949-|Chief executive officers--Singapore--Biography|Restaurants--Singapore|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Manufacturing industries>>Food, beverages and tobacco|Personalities
summary: Ip Yiu Tung (b. 1949, Hong Kong–) is the former group chairman and chief executive officer of restaurant chain Crystal Jade Culinary Concepts Holding. After joining Crystal Jade in 1992, he turned the ailing restaurant into a successful restaurant chain with multiple dining concepts and a presence in 18 cities across nine countries in Asia. In 2014, Ip sold Crystal Jade to L Capital Asia, the private-equity arm of French luxury goods giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton. He now serves as an adviser and brand ambassador for Crystal Jade. Originally from Hong Kong, he became a Singapore permanent resident in 2008.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Colonial Administrators|Black, Sir Robert Brown, 1906-1999|Colonial administrators--Singapore--Biography|Governors--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Law and government>>Political process>>Leadership|nlbdltx:History>>Asia>>Southeast Asia>>Singapore|Colonial administrators
summary: Robert Brown Black (Sir) (b. 3 June 1906, Edinburgh, Scotland–d. 29 October 1999, Reading, England), also known as Robin, was the governor and commander-in-chief of Singapore from 1955 to 1957. An early dispute with the chief minister led to the governor’s powers being curbed, but during his term of governance Black handled a stormy political situation with equanimity and patience, helping to ensure that Singapore was more stable when he left and ready for self-government.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies|Goi, Seng Hui, 1949-|Businesspeople--Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Business, finance and industry>>Industry>>Manufacturing industries>>Food, beverages and tobacco|Personalities
summary: Goi Seng Hui (b. 1949, Fuqing, China–) is an entrepreneur and investor nicknamed Singapore’s “Popiah King”. His company, Tee Yih Jia, is reportedly the largest producer of spring-roll skins in the world. Also known as Sam Goi, he is often cited as a role model for Singaporean entrepreneurs, having developed Tee Yih Jia from a small business with an annual turnover of S$300,000 into a global company with revenues in the hundreds of millions.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Authors|Lim, Catherine Poh Imm, 1942-|Women authors, Singapore--Biography|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Literatures>>East and Southeast Asian literature>>Singapore literature|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Fiction|Writers
summary: Catherine Lim Poh Imm (b. 21 March 1942, Penang, Malaysia–) is the doyenne of Singapore stories having written more than nine collections of short stories, five novels and a poetry book. She began as a teacher; then project director with the Ministry of Education; specialist lecturer with the Regional Language Centre (RELC); and finally became a full-time writer in 1992. She has won national and regional book prizes for her literary contributions. Her works are studied in local and foreign schools and universities, and have been published in various languages in several countries.

subject: nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Authors|nlbshtx:Arts>>Literature>>English (Singapore) Literature>>Fiction|Chua, Dave, 1970- --Biography|Award winners--Singapore--Biography|Authors, Singaporean--Biography|nlbdltx:Language and literature>>Literatures>>East and Southeast Asian literature>>Singapore literature|Writers |Fiction
summary: Dave Chua Hak Lien (b. 1970, Malaysia–), author of the novel Gone Case, was the recipient of the Singapore Literature Prize Commendation Award in 1996. He had been the joint recipient of the SPH-NAC Golden Point Award (short story category) for his work, Father’s Gift, the previous year.

subject: nlbshtx:Politics and Government|nlbshtx:Personalities>>Biographies>>Political Leaders|Political development |Politicians |Politics and Government
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) is a political party founded by Chiam See Tong in 1980. The party is currently led by chairman Paul Tambyah and secretary-general Chee Soon Juan.
